data.title: Cardinal Aloysius Ambrozic, former archbishop of Toronto, dead at 81
data.meta_description: He started life in the midst of the 20th century’s most tragic and tumultuous events and eventually went on to play a leading part in the life of Toronto’s Roman Ca…
data.text:
Article content

He started life in the midst of the 20th century’s most tragic and tumultuous events and eventually went on to play a leading part in the life of Toronto’s Roman Catholic community as its Archbishop and in the Church worldwide as a Cardinal.

On Friday, Cardinal Aloysius Ambrozic died at the age of 81 after a lengthy illness. He was man of intense dedication to his vocation and during his 56 years as a priest he was honoured for his service by being named a Cardinal by Pope John Paul II.“From start to finish he was a good and faithful servant and a humble man,” said Archbishop Thomas Collins, who took Cardinal Ambrozic’s place in 2006. “That is incredibly noble. His steady devotion was exemplary and the effect of that on others lasts over time.”

Article content

As the Archbishop of Toronto, Cardinal Ambrozic was instrumental in organizing the 2002 World Youth Day in which more than 750,000 people came to the city to worship with John Paul II.

“World Youth Day was just a monumental event and the effects are still found in vocations to the priesthood today,” said Archbishop Collins. “It was a tremendous gift to Toronto, Canada and the whole world.”

He was named Cardinal in 1998 by Pope John Paul II and when the pontiff passed away in 2005 he was part of the conclave that elected Pope Benedict XVI in that same year.

Cardinal Ambrozic was born in 1930 in Gaberje, Slovenia, the second of seven children. In May 1945, the entire family fled to Austria, living in several refugee camps. After completing high school in Austria his family came to Canada in 1948.

He entered St. Augustine’s Seminary in Toronto a short time later.

After almost 21 years as a diocesan priest, Fr. Ambrozic was named an Auxiliary Bishop for the Archdiocese of Toronto in 1976. Bishop Ambrozic served alongside Archbishop Philip Pocock and Cardinal Emmett Carter, before his appointment as Archbishop of Toronto on March 17, 1990. He was named Cardinal eight years later.

Article content

He spent 16 years as the city’s Archbishop. Under Church law, he had to retire his position in 2006 when he turned 75.

Archbishop Collins said that Cardinal Ambrozic was also known in academic circles as a great Biblical scholar. The Cardinal’s book on the Gospel of Mark, The Hidden Kingdom, is considered one of the classics in the field, he said.

But he noted the most remarkable thing about Cardinal Ambrozic was not his involvement with spectacular events but in remaining a man of such steady faith for so many years.

“That’s the heart of it. Just to be a steady and devoted in his mission as a priest and as a bishop. It is really important for priests to know their bishop is faithfully serving the Lord. That faithful service is what we saw in Cardinal Ambrozic.”

National Post

• Email: clewis@nationalpost.com | Twitter: holycharlie

The Cardinal will lie in state at St. Michael’s Cathedral for a public viewing, dates and times to be determined. His funeral Mass will also take place at the Cathedral.
